items.title: Deprecation warning due to invalid escape sequences

labels.name: technical
labels.description: Technical work without direct user impact.

items.body:
Deprecation warnings are raised due to invalid escape sequences. This can be fixed by using raw strings or escaping the literals. pyupgrade also helps in automatic conversion : https://github.com/asottile/pyupgrade/

```
find . -iname '*.py' | grep -Ev 'vendor|example|doc' | xargs -P4 -I{} python3.8 -Wall -m py_compile {}
./gmplot/utility.py:370: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \(
  '\(.*\)', # Matches whatever makes up the type, like:     '''(*(**float**, **float**)*)'''
./gmplot/utility.py:479: DeprecationWarning: invalid escape sequence \[
  match = re.match('!\[image]\((.*)\)', line, flags=re.DOTALL)
```

items.title: Use keyworded arguments for optional parameters.

labels.name: technical
labels.description: Technical work without direct user impact.

items.body:
In functions like `heatmap()`...
```python
def heatmap(self, lats, lngs, threshold=10, radius=10, gradient=None, opacity=0.6, maxIntensity=1, dissipating=True)
```
...the many optional parameters makes the function definition longer than it should be, hurting its readability and maintainability (a contributer might accidentally add a new parameter in the middle instead of at the very end, breaking the interface).

It also makes it tougher to introduce API changes; in the above case, removing `threshold` (which is deprecated) would break this interface for all users calling this function with positional arguments, as in the following example:
```python
heatmap(lats, lngs, 10, 15) # silent bug; if `threshold` is removed,
                            # `radius` will be set to 10 (instead of 15)
                            # and `gradient` will be set to 15
```

---

Using `kwargs`...
```python
def heatmap(self, lats, lngs, **kwargs)
```
...would help make gmplot's interfaces more robust; users won't be able to pass in optional parameters as positional arguments, so a smaller subset of users would be affected by any future interface changes.

With this implemented, the above example would look like:
```python
heatmap(lats, lngs, radius=15) # if `threshold` (or any other optional parameter)
                               # is removed from the interface, this function call
                               # won't be affected
```

items.title: Google API Keys not accepted while using gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter.from_geocode
items.body:
Below code fails, but should work:-

import gmplot
gmap2 = gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter.from_geocode("Jonkoping, Sweden", 13)
gmap2.draw(".\\out\\map12.html")

**Root cause:**
1. from_geocode creates a new instance, and then even when API key passed during instance creation is lost while doing this.
2. http is no longer allowed by google, so geocode fails in any case.

**Fix for this (proper):**
gmplot.py:-
from_geocode should have APIKey as a new parameter.
And then cls() should use that parameter as well.
This parameter should then be extended to geocode method, and accordingly the conditioning be done for http or https in geocode.

I have tested a fix for this and works:-
   def from_geocode(cls, location_string, zoom=13, pApiKey=''):
        lat, lng = cls.geocode(location_string, pApiKey)
        return cls(lat, lng, zoom, pApiKey)

   def geocode(self, location_string, pApikey=''):
        if pApikey == '':
            geocode = requests.get(
                'http://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address="%s"' % location_string)
        else:
            geocode = requests.get(
                'https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address="%s"' % location_string + "&key=" + pApikey)

 These two pieces shall solve it.

Regards,
Neeraj Kumar

items.title: does not show the marker without modifications
items.body:
to show the marker i've changed a little the lib source to this:
```python
def write_point(self, f, lat, lon, color, title):
    f.write('\t\tvar latlng = new google.maps.LatLng(%f, %f);\n' %
            (lat, lon))
    #f.write('\t\tvar img = new google.maps.MarkerImage(\'%s\');\n' %
            #(self.coloricon % color))
    f.write('\t\tvar marker = new google.maps.Marker({\n')
    f.write('\t\ttitle: "%s",\n' % title)
    #f.write('\t\ticon: img,\n')
    f.write('\t\tposition: latlng\n')
    f.write('\t\t});\n')
    f.write('\t\tmarker.setMap(map);\n')
    f.write('\n')
```

without this,the marker turns into transparent so it is invisible

Hello everyone, 

I have an issue regarding scatter(). I will attach several prints of the code and the output. The code invokes the function full_map which draws markers, scatter points, activates api key and draws the html. The function **scatter** invokes .scatter method (where I have the issue). 
![print1](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41108785/63586675-d1adb080-c599-11e9-8cd1-d12529190132.PNG)
![print2](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/41108785/63586676-d1adb080-c599-11e9-8ab3-f0a1c8348e0a.PNG)

Basically, I create the gmap object with gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter() with the coordinates of the city Cascais in Portugal. 

After that, I am using gmap.marker to mark those purple markers that are seen on the map.

items.title: Invalid syntax error with async
items.body:
I'm trying to use SOM in Python 3.7

```
def

 insertapikey(fname, apikey):
    """put the google api key in a html file"""
    def putkey(htmltxt, apikey, apistring=None):
        """put the apikey in the htmltxt and return soup"""
        if not apistring:
            apistring = "https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/js?key=%s&callback=initMap"
        soup = BeautifulSoup(htmltxt, 'html.parser')
        body = soup.body
        src = apistring % (apikey,)
     **tscript = soup.new_tag("script", src=src, async="defer")**
        body.insert(-1, tscript)
        return soup
    htmltxt = open(fname, 'r').read()
    soup = putkey(htmltxt, apikey)
    newtxt = soup.prettify()
    open(fname, `'w').write(newtxt)

```
And when I tried to run it, I received a SyntaxError: 

```
 File "<ipython-input-1-a2f7ce0b4338>", line 75
    tscript = soup.new_tag("script", src=src, async="defer")
                                                ^
SyntaxError: invalid syntax
```

What can be wrong?

items.title: Geocode Bugs
items.body:
GoogleMapPlotter.geocode
It needs a API to get results.

Change: `'http://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address="%s"' % location_string)`

To: `'https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address={}&key={}'.format(location_string, self.apikey))`

items.title: Add support for map.fitbounds
items.body:
When it is difficult to calculate the correct zoom level to show an specific area of the map, google maps allow the use of Map.fitBounds. It basically needs only the NE and SW coordinates:
https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/reference/3/map#Map.fitBounds

I have added the support for it in my fork, and I would like to do it in the main branch if approved. My only questions is. Should this be added as a separate function? something like `def fit_bounds(self, nelat, nelng, swlat, swlng):` or as a different way to initialize the map. That means providing NE and SW instead of `center_lat, center_lng, zoom`.

items.title: Should use matplotlib marker names internally for consistency.
items.body:
When merging new scatter plot types, I realize that we refer to them as CIRCLE, XMARK, and CROSS whereas matplotlib would refer to them as "circle", "x", and "plus". For clarity, they should be renamed internally to CIRCLE_MARKER, X_MARKER, PLUS_MARKER. These aren't really exposed to the public api, so it should be backwards compatible. @OmriRoames 

https://matplotlib.org/api/markers_api.html

items.title: Draw cannot return raw html. Incorrect description.
items.body:
Description of 'draw' says:

- Create the html file which include one google map and all points and paths. **If no string is provided, return the raw html.**

This does not match the the actual code. Not providing a string results in a crash.

items.title: Use of StringIO make module incompatible with Python 3
items.body:
Hi @vgm64 ,

The [introduction of StringIO](https://github.com/vgm64/gmplot/blob/master/gmplot/gmplot.py#L6) makes the module not compatible with Python 3.
 
Raises: `ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'StringIO'`, see more [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/11914472/stringio-in-python3).

I haven't encountered any other incompatibilities with python 3 apart from this one, so I wonder whether the feature implemented in [this recent commit](https://github.com/vgm64/gmplot/commit/ad6df42e96f9c3accefe691212af06376706f96e) is worth the generating an incompatibility. 

Perhaps there is an alternative way of implementing it?

items.title: gmplot.py write_point problem.
items.body:
```
        f.write('\t\tvar img = new google.maps.MarkerImage(\'%s\');\n' %
                (self.coloricon % color))

```
Causes an error when coloricon is a path containing backslashes.

Suggestion:

change init function:
from :
self.coloricon = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'markers/%s.png')
to:
self.coloricon = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'markers/%s.png').replace('\\', '/')

items.title: Calling `from_geocode` occasionally produces "list index out of range" error
items.body:
I've been using gmplot to draw running routes (via tcx files).  Until recently I could loop through a file list and generate the new html plots.

But now the loop will seemingly-spontaneously fail and generate the following error:

> 
>      40             'http://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address="%s"' % location_string)
>      41         geocode = json.loads(geocode.text)
> ---> 42         latlng_dict = geocode['results'][0]['geometry']['location']
>      43         return latlng_dict['lat'], latlng_dict['lng']
>      44 
> 
> IndexError: list index out of range


I was able to isolate it to the call for 
`gmap = gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter.from_geocode("San Francisco")`

For example, running the following code will result in throwing an error at some point (usually in the 8-14 range):

```
for i in range(25):
    print(i)
    gmap = gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter.from_geocode("San Francisco")

```

I can wrap it in a try/except but that merely delays the break.

My naive guess is that I'm breaking some API limit.

items.title: Add differnt markers
items.body:
Hi there,
I like to visualize a route with gmplot. This route has single origin, single destination, and multiple way points. I'd like to add different marker for all origin, destination, and way points. I tried this but it doesn't work. It keep just the last change and make all markers identical to this last change. Any help will be appreciated.
  
    def plot_markers(self, gm_plotter, lats, lngs, titles):
        """
        This method plot marker to GoogleMapPlotter. Where lats[0] and lngs[0] is the origin, lats[-1] and lngs[-1] 
        is the desination, and all the inbetween are waypoints. 
        :param gm_plotter: GoogleMapPlotter object
        :param lats: (list of floats) a list of latitudes
        :param lngs: (list of floats) a list of longitudes.
        :return: (GoogleMapPlotter) google map plotter object that could be for further processing.
        """
        gm_plotter.coloricon = 'http://www.googlemapsmarkers.com/v1/'+titles[0]+'/%s/FFFFFF/0080ff/' 
        gm_plotter.marker(lats[0], lngs[0], title=titles[0])
        gm_plotter.coloricon = 'http://www.googlemapsmarkers.com/v1/' + titles[-1] + '/%s/FFFFFF/0080ff/'
        gm_plotter.marker(lats[-1], lngs[-1], title=titles[-1])
        for lat, lng, title in zip(lats[1:-1], lngs[1:-1], titles[1:-1]):
            gm_plotter.coloricon = 'http://www.googlemapsmarkers.com/v1/' + title + '/%s/FFFFFF/0080ff/'
            gm_plotter.marker(lat, lng, title=title)
        return gm_plotter

items.title: contributing code examples pls
items.body:
Hello there,
This project was helpful in completing an assignment using gmplot to plot various specific coordinates and it was quite simple and easy to follow; here's an working example
https://github.com/drbhatt/gmplot_example

Appreciated your help and support.
Thanks.

items.title: Color progression with time
items.body:
Hi, thanks a lot fo this project, it's very useful. Btw this is more suggestion rather than an issue. So the idea is to create color progression with each coordinate to display the order at which some movement occured. It could be done for example by something like this:

#example of usage
`gmap.scatter(latitudes, longitudes, '#3B0B39', size=40, marker=False, progressive=True) `

#implementation in gmplot
`
    def BuildColor(self, r, g, b):
        newClr = "#"
        for num in [r,g,b]:
            newClr += (hex(num)[2:] if len(hex(num)[2:]) > 1 else "0" + hex(num)[2:])
        return newClr

    def scatter(self, lats, lngs, color=None, size=None, marker=True, c=None, s=None, progressive=False, **kwargs):
        color = color or c
        size = size or s or 40
        kwargs["color"] = color
        kwargs["size"] = size
        settings = self._process_kwargs(kwargs)
        print settings['color']
        counter = 0
        for lat, lng in zip(lats, lngs):
            if progressive == True:
                r = int(255.0 / float(len(lats)) * counter)
                g = int(255.0 - (255.0 / float(len(lats)) * counter))
                b = 0
                counter+=1
                settings['color'] = self.BuildColor(r,g,b)
                #print r, g, b
                #print settings['color']
            if marker:
                self.marker(lat, lng, settings['color'])
            else:
                self.circle(lat, lng, size, **settings)`

I edited the gmplot myself (I know it's not perfect :P especially that it's just "green -> red" and making the original color setting useless) but it would be cool if something like this was available in further updates.

items.title: text display at given GPS coordinates

items.title: Add optional WeightedLocation
items.body: Google maps API accepted WeightedLocation as an alternative to Location when plotting heatmaps. gmplot is unable to accept weights in the heatmap function. As a result, gmplot cannot be used with numerically weighted locations.

items.title: Setting alpha=0 is ignored
items.body:
Setting either of the alpha values to 0.0 is ignored due to the way the code is implemented. e.g.:

kwargs.get("alpha", None) or \
                                 kwargs.get("face_alpha", None) or \
                                 kwargs.get("fa", None) or \
                                 0.3

will result in 0.3 if given face_alpha=0.0, because 0.0 is converted to False

items.title: NameError: name 'latitudes' is not defined
items.body:
I installed the newest version of gmplot on my machine. but when I execute the sample code:
import gmplot

gmap = gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter(37.428, -122.145, 16)

gmap.plot(latitudes, longitudes, 'cornflowerblue', edge_width=10)
gmap.scatter(more_lats, more_lngs, '#3B0B39', size=40, marker=False)
gmap.scatter(marker_lats, marker_lngs, 'k', marker=True)
gmap.heatmap(heat_lats, heat_lngs)

gmap.draw("mymap.html")

It gave me the following error message.

NameError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-1-0f1e59eccdc3> in <module>()
      3 gmap = gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter(37.428, -122.145, 16)
      4 
----> 5 gmap.plot(latitudes, longitudes, 'cornflowerblue', edge_width=10)
      6 gmap.scatter(more_lats, more_lngs, '#3B0B39', size=40, marker=False)
      7 gmap.scatter(marker_lats, marker_lngs, 'k', marker=True)

NameError: name 'latitudes' is not defined

What is going on with my operation here?

items.title: miss info_window
items.body: Where is info_window method gone?

items.title: .scatter method does not take lists as input for "s" or "size" parameter
items.body: Hello, thank you for this amazing library. Very much like the matplotlib interface. I was wondering if there is a way that the .scatter method accepts a list/tuple as input for the "size" parameter.  In matplotlib scatter plots the "s" parameter accepts lists, so that the bubble size can be adjusted for each datapoint. This would also be a great feature for gmplot. Regards, Johannes

items.title: Marker path doesn't work on Windows
items.body:
I have just installed a script that works fine on OSX onto a windows box with Python27.   

When I run the script and create a HTML file it doesn't render any markers.

Looking at the Chrome console I see:
file:///C:/Python27libsite-packagesgmplotmarksers/FFA500.png 
ERR_FILE_NOT_FOUND

It seems that the path separator is incorrect and not used.

Looking at the actual HTML file the path separators are all backslashes

Changing the HTML to use forward slash as separator seems to work,

items.title: Enabling API key handling (MissingKeyMapError)
items.body: It looks like Google Maps no longer allows key-less API access [as of yesterday June 22th](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/37991340/error-google-maps-api-error-missingkeymaperror). This will probably require to enable passing an API key to gmplot. Currently using gmplot fails with `MissingKeyMapError`.

items.title: add a link to GMaps visualization lib
items.body: https://developers.google.com/maps/documentation/javascript/visualization contains a rich set of information (and it's what gmplot uses) so maybe add a link to it in the readme? f.e. it contains all the description for the class parameters

items.title: gmplot in the HTML title?
items.body: maybe https://github.com/vgm64/gmplot/blob/master/gmplot/gmplot.py#L181 should be changed to include 'gmplot' instead of pygmaps?

items.title: from_geocode() is now included in GoogleMapPlotter
items.body:
the  doc states:

gmap = gmplot.from_geocode("San Francisco")

but it should actually be

gmap = gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter.from_geocode("San Francisco")
